lines.text: My speech! Here's my Christmas speech. Ahem. "Thank you all, and Merry Christmas."
That was the speech?
It was dumb!
It was obvious!
It was pointless!
It was... short!
[turns to Robert]
I loved it!
"Never eat singing food."
heights, and jumping from them.
Too late now. Come on, I'll catch you.
God save my little broken body!
[Jumps and falls to the ground. He looks at Gonzo]
Missed.
Oh wait a second... I forgot my jellybeans. Um...
[Slides through the bars to retrieve them, and joins Gonzo back on the other side. Gonzo stares at him]
What?
You can fit through those bars?
Yeah...
You are such an idiot.
If you please Mr. Scrooge, it's gotten colder, and the bookkeeping staff would like an extra shovel full of coal for the fire?
We can't do the bookkeeping, all our pens have turned to inkcicles!
Our assets are frozen!
How would the bookkeeping staff like to be suddenly... UNEMPLOYED?

[singing]
HEAT WAVE. This is my island in the sun...
Tomorrow, you become a man of business!
I'm looking forward to it, Headmaster.
Mm, you will love business. It is the AMERICAN WAY!

[whispers]
Sam...
[whispers in Sam's ear]
Oh... It is the BRITISH WAY!
Yes, headmaster.
Boy, that's scary stuff! Should we be worried about the kids in the audience?
Nah, it's all right. This is culture!
[an urchin steals a talking vegetable]
Hey, I'm being stolen! Hey, help me! Help me!
Bob Cratchit, I've had my fill of this.
And I have had my fill of you, Mr. Scrooge.
And therefore, Bob Cratchit...
And therefore, you can leave this house at once.
And therefore, I'm about to raise your salary!
Ooh, and I am about to raise you right off the pavement...! Pardon?
Pardon?
Why do you doubt your senses?

Because a little thing can effect them. A slight disorder of the stomach can make them cheat. You may be a bit of undigested beef, a blob of mustard, a crumb of cheese. Yes. There's more gravy than of grave about you.
More gravy than of grave?
What a terrible pun. Where do you get those jokes?
Leave comedy to the bears, Ebenezer.
We were always heckling you.
It's good to be heckling again.
It's good to be doing anything again.

[a nearby clock strikes the hour]
Oh, what was that?
Two o'clock.
Is it too early for breakfast?
Yes.
Oh good, suppertime!
If he became a flavor you can bet he would be sour. Yuck!
Even the vegetables don't like him!
Work hard, lad, and one day, your life will be as solid as this very building!
[the shelf collapses behind him]
Huh. I've been meaning to fix that shelf!
My name is Charles Dickens.
And my name is Rizzo the Rat... wait a second! You're not Charles Dickens!
I am too!
No! A blue furry Charles Dickens who hangs out with a rat?
Absolutely!
Charles Dickens was a 19th Century novelist! A genius!
Oh, you are too kind!
Why should I believe you?
Well, because I know the story of A Christmas Carol like the back of my hand!
Prove it!
All right! Um, there's a little mole on my thumb, and um, a scar on my wrist from when I fell off my bike...
No, no, no, don't tell us your *hand*, tell us the *story*!

[in the graveyard]
Must we return to this place? There is something else that I must know, is that not true? Spirit, I know what I must ask. I fear to, but I must. Who was the wretched man whose death brought so much glee and happiness to others?
[the spirit points to a headstone, Scrooge begins moving toward it, then turns back, frightened]
Answer me one more question. Are these the shadows of things that *will* be, or are they the shadows of things that *may* be only?
[the spirit points again at the gravestone, Scrooge slowly approaches it]
These events can be changed! A life can be made right.
[he clears the snow from the stone and reads]

[in tears]
Ebenezer Scrooge! Oh please Spirit, no! Hear me, I, I am not the man I was! Why would you show me this if I am past all hope?...
[sobbing]

I, I *will* honor Christmas, and try to keep it all the year! I will live my life in the past, the present and the future. I will not shut out the lessons the spirits have taught me! Tell me that I may sponge out the writing on this stone!
[kneeling, clutching at the spirit's robe]
Oh Spirit, please speak to me!
[Gonzo and Rizzo are flying over London]

[Thrilled]
Hello, London!

[Scared]
Goodbye, lunch!
Once again, I must ask you to remember that the Marleys were dead, and decaying in their graves.
Yuck!

[whispering]
That one thing you must remember, or nothing that follows will seem wondrous.
Why are you whispering?
It's for dramatic emphasis.
What right have you to be merry? You're poor enough.
What right have you to be dismal? You're rich enough.
He's got 'im there. The old boy's speechless!
If I could work my will, every idiot who goes around with "a Merry Christmas" on his lips would be cooked with his own turkey and buried with a stake of holly through his heart!
Well, not quite speechless.

Christmas is a very busy time for us, Mr. Cratchit. People preparing feasts, giving parties, spending the mortgage money on frivolities. One might say that December is the foreclosure season. Harvest time for the money-lenders.
[Scrooge has met the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come]
Oh, this is too scary. I don't think I wanna see any more!
When you're right, you're right.
[turning to face the audience]
You're on your own, folks. We'll meet you at the finale!
Yeah!
He was a tight-fisted hand at the grindstone, Scr...
[noticing the smudged window of Scrooge's office]
Boy, this really *is* a dirty city!
Heh, you're tellin' me!
[Gonzo grabs Rizzo and uses him to wipe off the window pane]

[sarcastically]
Thank you for makin' me a part of this!
a squeezing, wrenching, grasping, clutching, covetous old sinner.
I fell down the chimney and landed on a flaming hot goose!
You have all the fun!
I don't think I've ever met anybody like you before.
Really? Over 1800 of my brothers have come before me!
1800? Imagine the grocery bills!
It's all right, children. Life is made up of meetings and partings. That is the way of it. I am sure that we shall never forget Tiny Tim, or this first parting that there was among us.
Oh, Gonzo, speak to me! I mean, Mr. Dickens. Charlie! Are you hurt?

[gets up]
To say that Scrooge became startled would be untrue. Still the moment had passed, and the world was as it should be.
He ain't hurt. Didn't even lose his concentration.
Let us deal with the eviction notices for tomorrow, Mr. Cratchit.
Uh, tomorrow's Christmas, sir.
Very well. You may gift wrap them.
[Scrooge has thrown Mr Applegate out of the office]
Thank you for not shouting at me!
I do not make merry at Christmas...
That is certainly true.
And I cannot afford to make other people merry.
That is certainly *not* true!

[falls down a chimney ignoring Gonzo]
Hey! I'm stuck! Get me out of here!
I knew you weren't suited for literature.
I've got his blankets.
Ah, his blankets... Why, Mrs. Dilber, they're still warm! I don't pay extra for the warmth, you know.
You should. It's the only warmth he ever had.
This is Bob Crachit's house?
How do you know that?
You just told me.
Well, I'm *usually* trustworthy.
I'll see you tomorrow morning at 8.

[whispering]
Ask him, ask him.
Tomorrow's Christmas, sir.
30, then.
Uh, if you please Mr. Scrooge, half an hour off hardly seems customary for Christmas Day.
No, no.
How much time off *is* customary?
Why, uh... The whole day.
Yeah, yeah!
The *entire* day?
No, no. That's the frog's idea...
Spirit, show me no more. Why do you delight in torturing me?
I told you, these are the shadows of the things that have been. That they are what they are, do not blame me.
Leave Me!

[as they sit together]
Another year before our wedding, Ebenezer.
Well, it can't be helped, Belle. How could we marry now? There's not even enough for a decent home. The investments haven't grown as they should.
So you said last year.
Business continues to be poor.
You're a partner in your own firm now.
And barely clearing expenses.
You said the partnership was the goal.
This is for you.
[turns to Belle]
I love you, Belle.
You did once.
You will be haunted by three spirits.
Haunted? I've already had enough of that.
Without these visits, you cannot hope to avoid the path we tread.
Expect the first ghost tonight, when the bell tolls one!
Can't I meet them all at once and get it over with?
Light the lamp, not the rat, light the lamp, not the rat! Put me out, put me out, put me out!
Oh! My apologies! Um...
[Suddenly spotting a barrel of water below the lamp post]
Rizzo!
What?
["Mr Dickens" pushes Rizzo so he falls into the water barrel]
At this time in the proceedings, it is a tradition for me to make a little speech.
And it's a tradition for us to take a little nap!
You're a little absent-minded, spirit.
No, I'm a LARGE absent-minded spirit!
What business has brought you here?
Your welfare.
Heh, a night's unbroken rest might aid my welfare.
Your salvation, then.
There was of course, another Christmas Eve with this young woman. Some years later.
Oh please... do not show me that Christmas.
Rats don't understand these things.
You were never a lonely child?
I had twelve hundred and seventy four brothers and sisters.
Boy! Rats don't understand these things!
It was the afternoon of Christmas Eve and Scrooge was conscious of a thousand odors, each one connected with a thousand thoughts and hopes and joys and cares long, long forgotten.
[Rizzo and "Mr. Dickens" are sitting on the window ledge outside Scrooge's bedroom]

[looking around]
Um, are you sure it's safe for us to be up here?
Scrooge is saved. What can happen now?
Yeah.
[Scrooge opens the window, knocking Rizzo and "Mr. Dickens" off the ledge]
If you please sir, why open the office tomorrow? Other businesses will be closed; there'll be no one to do business with. It'll waste a lot of expensive coal for the fire!
Yeah!
It's a poor excuse for picking a man's pocket every December the 25th. But as I seem to be the only man who knows that... take the day off.

[Having just watched the Cratchits mourning Tiny Tim, addresses the Ghost of Christmas Yet To Come]
Oh, spirit, must there be a Christmas that brings this awful scene?
[Voice breaking]
How can we endure it?
How do you know what Scrooge is doin'? We're down here and he's up there!
I told you, storytellers are omniscient; I know everything!
Hoity-toity, Mr. Godlike Smarty-Pants.
To conduct a proper search, Scrooge was forced to light the lamps.
[the lamps come on]
How *does* he do that?
Hello! Welcome to the Muppet Christmas Carol! I am here to tell the story.
And I am here for the food.
Let us see another Christmas in this place.
They were all very much the same. Nothing ever changed.
You changed.
Belle, you know, I love these annual Christmas parties. I love 'em so much, I think we'll do it twice a year!

[brushing past Belle and Fozziwig]
Excuse me.
[he sees Belle and is instantly attracted]
Oh... Excuse me.
Oh, Master Scrooge! Belle, I'd like you to meet Mr. Ebenezer Scrooge... the finest young financial mind in the city! Ebenezer, this is Belle! A friend of the Fozziwig family.
I'm pleased to meet you.
[she offers her hand, Scrooge kisses it]
Well, I'm glad you two finally met.
Look, it's Ebeneezer Scrooge!
Looking older and more wicked than ever.
I knew he wouldn't disappoint us!
[Describing Fozziwig]
What an employer he was. As hard and ruthless as a rose petal!
Boomerang fish! Guaranteed fresh! Throw the fish A-WAY... and it comes back to me! Get 'em while they're fresh!
Are you the spirit whose coming was foretold to me?
I am.
But... you're just a child!
I can remember nearly 1900 years. I am the Ghost of Christmas Past.
